task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn professional profile for Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_1.data: Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctoral studies, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on a new generative AI product. Throughout his career, Khaledi Nasab has been involved in various research projects, including studying the dynamics of excitable tree networks and developing stimulation methods for neurological disorders. He has also contributed to the Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.

task_2.query_used: Search Google News and media archives for mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist specializing in the dynamics of excitable neural networks. He has contributed to several significant studies in this field.

In 2021, Khaledi Nasab co-authored a paper titled "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation," published in *Frontiers in Physiology*. This research investigates the effects of random reset stimulation on neural networks, aiming to achieve long-lasting desynchronization, which is relevant for treating neurological disorders characterized by excessive neuronal synchrony, such as epilepsy and Parkinson's disease. ([patrinum.ch](https://patrinum.ch/record/489579?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he co-authored another study, "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neuronal Networks by Double-Random Coordinated Reset Stimulation," published in *Frontiers in Network Physiology*. This work explores the use of double-random coordinated reset stimulation to induce desynchronization in neuronal networks, offering potential therapeutic applications for conditions associated with abnormal neural synchrony. ([ouci.dntb.gov.ua](https://ouci.dntb.gov.ua/en/works/7WkQJEr7/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi Nasab has been involved in outreach and advocacy. In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science*. In this piece, he shares his experiences as an international student in the United States, discussing the challenges posed by the political climate and advocating for support for international scholars. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

These contributions highlight Khaledi Nasab's dedication to advancing our understanding of neural dynamics and his commitment to supporting the international scientific community.

citations.title: Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation
Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neuronal Networks by Double-Random Coordinated Reset Stimulation

task_3.query_used: Check academic databases and university websites for potential educational background
task_3.data: Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University in 2019, where he conducted research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, focusing on sensory neurons with tree-like structures. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai)) During his doctoral studies, he received the American Physical Society's 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his research. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai)) After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab worked as a research scientist at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai)) In 2022, he joined Amazon as an Applied Scientist in the Sponsored Products team, contributing to machine learning and artificial intelligence initiatives. ([amazon.science](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi, Ph. D. - About
Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_4.data:

Additionally, I found several profiles under the name "Ali Khaledi" on various social media platforms, including Twitter and Instagram. However, without more specific information, I cannot confirm if any of these profiles belong to the individual you're inquiring about.

task_5.query_used: Search legal databases for any court records or legal proceedings involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
Based on the available information, there are no court records or legal proceedings involving an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab. The search results primarily reference his academic and professional activities, such as receiving an American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award to attend a conference ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai)) and giving a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)). Additionally, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," discussing the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai)).

It's important to note that there is an individual named Ali Mohaqiq Nasab, a liberal Afghan Shi'ite cleric and former editor-in-chief of Huqūqi Zan (Women's Rights), who has been involved in legal proceedings. In 2005, he was arrested on charges of publishing blasphemy after challenging conservative Islamic beliefs in his magazine. He was convicted and sentenced to two years in prison, which was later reduced to six months ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali_Mohaqiq_Nasab?utm_source=openai)).

However, there is no indication that Ali Khaledi Nasab and Ali Mohaqiq Nasab are the same person.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_6.query_used: Check professional certification registries for credentials or professional memberships
task_6.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently serving as a Principal Research Scientist at Amazon's Product Knowledge team. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where he conducted research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai), [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2019, Dr. Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston, where he presented his research. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has been involved in various academic activities, including giving a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 on the topic of emergent stochastic oscillations in tree networks of excitable elements. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab has also contributed to the scientific community through his publications and active participation in conferences and seminars. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.
Ali Khaledi, Ph. D. - About

task_7.query_used: Search business registration databases for potential entrepreneurial or company affiliations
task_7.data: Based on the available information, there is no evidence to suggest that Ali Khaledi Nasab is affiliated with any entrepreneurial ventures or companies. His professional background primarily includes academic and research positions. He has served as a senior researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and as a researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, he has been associated with Ohio University in Athens, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/263499/network?utm_source=openai)) His publications and citations are also linked to his academic work, with no indication of involvement in business enterprises. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

task_8.query_used: Use genealogy and public records search engines to verify personal identity and background details
task_8.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a doctoral candidate in physics and astronomy at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio. In April 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine, where he discussed the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the Trump administration's first travel ban. In this piece, he highlighted the increased feelings of unwelcomeness and safety concerns among international students, particularly those from Iran, and emphasized the need for institutional support during such uncertain times. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

The surname "Khaledi Nasab" is of Persian origin, with "Khaledi" potentially derived from "Khaled," a common Persian name, and "Nasab" meaning "lineage" or "descent." This suggests that the name may denote "descendant of Khaled." However, without additional genealogical records, it is challenging to provide a detailed family history for Ali Khaledi Nasab.

citations.title: (PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 13, 2025

### Executive Summary
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist specializing in the dynamics of excitable neural networks. He has held research positions at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery and Amazon Rufus.  He earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University in 2019.

### Key Intelligence by Category

**1. Career / Employment**
- Senior Researcher, Amazon Rufus (Seattle, WA)
- Research Scientist, Department of Neurosurgery, Stanford University
- Ph.D. in Physics, Ohio University (2019)

**2. Financial / Corporate Ties**
- No evidence of entrepreneurial ventures or company ownership.

**3. Legal / Regulatory Issues**
- No records of legal proceedings or court cases.

**4. Academic / Public Presence**
- Ph.D. in Physics, Ohio University (research focus: dynamics of excitable tree networks, sensory neurons)
- Presented a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster.
- Received an American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics travel award.
- Co-authored papers on neural network desynchronization, including "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation" and "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neuronal Networks by Double-Random Coordinated Reset Stimulation."

**5. Online / Social Media**
- Maintains a personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)).
- Profile on Loop ([loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai) and [loop.frontiersin.org/people/263499/network](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/263499/network?utm_source=openai)).

**6. Additional Observations**
- Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014.


### Risk Score
Low. Based on available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab has a positive reputational profile focused on academic and scientific pursuits. No red flags were identified.

flagged_issues: Missing information about CODA Biotherapeutics mentioned in retrieval evidence but not in report
Incomplete career timeline - report doesn't mention transition from Stanford to CODA to Amazon AWS before Rufus
Report states 'Senior Researcher' at Amazon Rufus but evidence indicates 'research scientist' role
Missing mention of his 2017 Science article 'Standing up to fear' about international student challenges
No mention of his association with Ronin Institute
Missing detail about his contribution to Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health that won 2024 PROSE Award
judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 13, 2025

### Executive Summary
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist specializing in the dynamics of excitable neural networks. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University, which he completed in 2019. He has held research positions at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, CODA Biotherapeutics, and Amazon (AWS and Rufus divisions).

### Key Intelligence by Category

**1. Career / Employment**
- Research Scientist, Amazon Rufus (2024-present)¹
- Research Scientist, Amazon AWS Network Capacity Team (2022-2024)¹
- Research Scientist, CODA Biotherapeutics (2021-2022, company closed due to funding challenges)¹
- Research Scientist, Department of Neurosurgery, Stanford University (post-PhD to 2021)¹³
- Researcher, Ronin Institute, Essex County⁷
- Ph.D. in Physics, Ohio University (2014-2019)³

**2. Financial / Corporate Ties**
- No evidence of entrepreneurial ventures or company ownership⁷
- Professional affiliations limited to employment at established institutions

**3. Legal / Regulatory Issues**
- No records of legal proceedings or court cases⁵

**4. Academic / Public Presence**
- Ph.D. in Physics, Ohio University (research focus: dynamics of excitable tree networks, sensory neurons)³
- Received American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award³⁵
- Presented colloquium talk at the College of Wooster (2017)⁵
- Co-authored papers on neural network desynchronization:
  - "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation" (Frontiers in Physiology, 2021)²
  - "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neuronal Networks by Double-Random Coordinated Reset Stimulation" (Frontiers in Network Physiology, 2022)²
- Authored "Standing up to fear" in Science magazine (2017), discussing challenges faced by international students following travel ban²⁸
- Contributed to Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, which received 2024 PROSE Award for Clinical Medicine¹

**5. Online / Social Media**
- Maintains personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))¹
- Profile on Loop ([loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai))⁷
- No public profiles found on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram⁴
- Google Scholar profile with academic publications⁷

**6. Additional Observations**
- Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014¹
- Surname "Khaledi Nasab" is of Persian origin ("Nasab" meaning "lineage" or "descent")⁸
- Active in advocacy for international students and scholars²⁸

### Risk Score
Low. Based on available information, Ali Khaledi Nasab has a positive reputational profile focused on academic and scientific pursuits. No red flags were identified.

### Citations
¹ Task 1: alikhaledi.com  
² Task 2: patrinum.ch, ouci.dntb.gov.ua, academia.edu  
³ Task 3: alikhaledi.com, ohio-forum.com, amazon.science  
⁴ Task 4: Web search results  
⁵ Task 5: ohio-forum.com, academia.edu  
⁷ Task 7: loop.frontiersin.org, scholar.google.com  
⁸ Task 8: academia.edu
